text:
We will get started. For those joining us today
from all over the world,

welcome to section J's 2021
graduation diploma ceremony!
Give it up! Round of applause for everybody! [CLAPPING]

Beautiful. The chat is going. If you have comments, feel
free to make it in the chat

and put them in the chat. I am here to kick
things off formally.

My name is Yael
Grushka-Cockayne, and for those who
don't know me, I

am currently a professor
of business administration and a senior associate dean of
professional degree programs

at the Darden School of Business
at the University of Virginia. More relevant to today,
I am a former visiting

associate professor in the
technology and operations management unit at
Harvard Business School.

I taught section J,
these incredible people, their required course in
technology and operations

management during their
first year at HBS. Yes, that was in 2019.

Pre-COVID days. Incredible. You might think that it's a bit
unusual for a faculty from a,

a little bit competing
business school, to come and preside over a
graduation ceremony at HBS,

and you are correct. But like many other
things in their lives,

section J moves mountains
to get what they want,

and I am thankful
that they did so. I am truly, truly
honored to be here today

and to represent
section J's faculty. On behalf of the faculty, allow
me to be among the first--

I don't know-- the 10th, the
20th, to say, congratulations. You should all be
tremendously proud of what

you have accomplished
over the past two years. For the families and
friends, siblings,

and all the amazing people
that I'm seeing here, the Jones clan and everyone, I
want to say thank you

for all that you have done to
support section J graduates. I know that they would not
have made it to this point

without you. And in some case,
without letting them come back home and
crash in their bedrooms

to take Zoom classes
throughout the duration. I hope, on a serious note,
that everybody joining today

is arriving here right
now healthy and safe both mentally and physically.

Many people around
the world are not, and it is important that we're
all thankful for what we have

and that we find ways to
help those around us who don't have the health and
safety that we feel right now.

Before we move to
the diploma ceremony

and for just a few minutes-- I won't take long-- I wanted to talk to you all
about becoming and being real.

I want to start with a reading
from the Velveteen Rabbit by Marjorie Williams.

And I have the book-- I don't know if you can see it--
the book here today with me.

"It doesn't happen at
once, said the Skin Horse. You become.

It takes a long time. That's why it
doesn't often happen to people who break easily,
or have sharp edges,

or who have to be
carefully kept. Generally, by the time you
are real, most of your hair

has been loved off, and
your eyes dropped out and you get loose in the
joints and very shabby.

But these things don't matter at
all, because once you are real,

you can't be ugly except to
people who don't understand."

For those of you who don't
know the Velveteen Rabbit or are not familiar
with the story, this is a conversation between
two stuffed animals or two

toys. The Skin Horse continues,
"once you are real,
you cannot become unreal again. It lasts for always."

A lot has been said about
the challenges of the past 14 months and the
endurance and resilience

that it takes for those
engaged in demanding activities such as studying towards
a master's of business

administration at the
Harvard Business School to stay on task and persevere.

I am sure that all
of you can recognize in this group of amazing
graduates here today

these characteristics of
persistence, hard working, and perseverance towards a goal.

They wouldn't have been here
without those characteristics. I would like to focus
on their realness.

This group's ability
to support one another in bringing
their authentic self

to their engagements and
to everything that they do. It is simply remarkable.

Their encouragement of one
another to be themselves and to be proud of it
and let it shine through,

and it was there
from the beginning. Their ability to make one
another feel real is a gift--

a gift that I know I was honored
to receive and be part of, and the reason I'm here today.

Harvard Business
School's mission, which you've heard
several times today, is to educate leaders who make
a difference in the world.

Achieving this mission in
today's complex and fast-moving world requires an environment
of trust, mutual respect,

free expression,
inquiry, and a commitment to truth, excellence,
and lifelong learning. We've said it before.

While I'm 100% confident that
the members of section J 2021 have already made a huge
difference in the world

and in so many meaningful ways,
interesting and exciting ways, I know that their
commitment to doing so

by creating an
environment of real people with all kinds of flaws
and specificities,

accepting the uniquenesses
in each and every one of us, and fostering a culture
that embraces everyone.

That is their gift. On a very personal
level, section J has always made sure that
I know I can be myself.

They met my kids and my family. They visited my house
and invited me to theirs.

They supported me through
some personal challenges and decisions and shared
with me their own struggles

and challenges. We kept it real. And by keeping it real, we
progressed, stayed close,

and excelled, knowing that if
we need to and if we need it, we have a group of 94
amazing, real people that we

can rely on. Two years ago, when
they were all brand new,

starting off the
most challenging time in their lives, I walked
into their HBS classroom for the very first time.

From the very first
RRC Tom Benihana case, the Shad Exercise, the coffee
breaks, Natalie's final class

show. Through many launches,
random meetings at the gym,

and My Take sessions,
it was obvious that section H wanted
to get to know me--

the real me. With all of my flaws
and my obsessions, with my disappointments
and my successes.

They valued my
friendship and my support just as much as they valued
my professional expertise

and knowledge. Class after class,
experience after experience,

section J demonstrated
their willingness to accept each
other in new ways.

As the year evolved and many
new challenges surfaced, section J rose to the
occasion and continued

to celebrate the individuals
that make this group special. I promised myself
I wouldn't tear up.

Section J, you helped me
learn and grow in so many ways I feel confident about
being authentically myself

at all times. You helped me consider
diverse new perspectives.

You helped me learn about
the true benefits of assuming positive intent and
empowered me to never stop

pushing myself to new things. On our last day of Tom classes,
Antonina-- is Antonina here?

Antonina made a comment
that I will never forget. You commented on my
hair color, suggesting

that by my following
my own style and walking into
class as myself, I brought calmness to your life.

In making that
comment in passing, you highlighted to me
how by being myself,

I can affect others. By being yourself and making
that comment, you affected me.

To give me faith
to follow my heart and show up in ways
that make me happy.

And you reminded
me that by making-- by doing so, I
make a difference.

Looking at this incredible
group in front of me, I see a group that uses its
real superpowers, its realness,

to make a difference
in others' lives and to be-- and to
authentically lead.

They are supportive, loving,
passionate, unique individuals with so much personality.

They bring themselves and are
proud of their imperfections. They are leaders by being
complete individuals

with stories and backgrounds. They are leaders
since they trust that their personalities are as
important as their credentials.

These have been two
eventful and not-easy years. Hard working, hours of
Zoom, class discussions.

Thousands of hours of learning. We developed meaningful
relationships that will endure.

You leave HBS today-- unbelievable-- to go on
to do amazing things.

Stay confident in
your real selves. It is magical. I have seen it.
Thank you, section J.

Thank you for
allowing me to express those words and my thoughts
and feelings to all of you.

And before we get to the moment
that we're all waiting for, which is the diploma
ceremony, we're

going to hear a few
words from Professor Jan Rivkin, the senior associate
dean chair of the HBS MBA
program.

Congratulations again
to the class of 2021. You are now officially
HBS graduates.

You know, graduation day is
my favorite day of the year. I love seeing our
students so happy.

I love seeing their
families and friends so rightly proud of their
graduates and so excited about their bright futures.

And we now come to
my favorite part of my favorite day of the
year-- the diploma ceremony,

where we recognize each and
every member of your section. As members of the class
of 2021 are recognized,

you'll hear mention of
three kinds of honors. The first is distinction. This is for students who
earned academic honors

in both the first year and the
second year of our program. The second is high distinction.

These individuals not only
earned honors in the first year in the second year. They also had a combined
academic performance

that placed them in the top
5% of their class as a whole. These students are also known
as George F. Baker Scholars,

commemorating the individual
whose generosity in the 1920s allowed us to build the campus.

I invite you to look
at the Baker Scholars page on the graduation
website to learn more about the legacy of George
Baker and this particular

distinction. Third and last, but by no
means least, the Dean's Award.

The Dean's Award celebrates
the extraordinary achievements of graduating students who,
during their time at HBS,

made distinctive contributions
to Harvard, to Harvard Business School, or the
broader community.

These students have contributed
to the well-being of others through amazing
acts of leadership.

Students and all
members of the community nominate these individuals,
and then Dean Datar makes the final selection.

So please enjoy the
diploma ceremony. Celebrate each and every
member of your session.

I hope that your session will
remain closed through the years as mine has, and I hope
that these two years at HBS

will be just the beginning of an
ongoing conversation among you as you enjoy long, happy
years of making differences

that are meaningful to you
and meaningful for the world. Be well, and stay close.
Beautiful.

Are we all ready for the
diploma ceremony, guys? Are we ready for the
diplomacy ceremony? [APPLAUSE]

We will now move to
the diploma ceremony. It will be a few minutes.

We will go through
the names one by one. We will read-- there will be
an announcement of the awards when your name appears.

Feel free to unmute
yourself, make some noise, celebrate each other,
and I look forward

to seeing you after the diploma
ceremony video is shown. Let's kick it off with the
diploma ceremony, please.
Here we go. [MUSIC PLAYING]

[READING NAMES, CHEERING AND
 APPLAUSE]

Beautiful. Congratulations to everybody. Congratulations to
the award winners and to everybody who is part
of the section J family.

What we want to do
now is we want to, before we have
our final segment, we want to make sure that
we have an opportunity

to take photos of this amazing
gallery, folks in cap and gown if they want to be, but
they don't have to be. If you have your own camera
and you're in the room,

turn on your video now. We're going to do
a few snapshots so you can take some
photos and screen shares
of the photos of everybody. So everybody get ready. Good? Set your hair right.

Good? Everybody good? [INAUDIBLE],, tell me
when you're ready. Good? OK?
[INAUDIBLE] Really proud of you. Are we good? Everybody on? As many as we can?
Oh, look at that. Champagne glasses. I like it. I didn't get the memo. OK, folks.

Raise your glass if you have it. We're going to take some
snapshots if you can. We're going to take
some snapshots.
One, two, three, snap it.

Good. And let's do another one. Now, we're going to move to
the other side of the gallery.

Everybody do a different pose. Different pose. We want to make sure that
we have a different pose.

This is the photo time! Bring your family in! Ah, John. Very formal. Back to back. You guys can do
Charlie's Angels.
OK, beautiful. Let's do another one. Congratulations, section J!
Wonderful! Fantastic. Thank you so much, everybody.
Have a drink. Go for it. Now's your time. Fantastic.
OK, we're back in our session. Everybody's here.

Congratulations again
to all of our graduates. And we couldn't finish
the ceremony here today

or our little event here today
without really taking a moment to thank all the families
and friends that got us here

for your support. We have a special
little surprise for you. But before we move
to the surprise,

as my help here, Dylan,
is setting it up, if you're near your loved ones
right now, give them a hug.

Give them a kiss. Thank them. Do what we couldn't do all year. Thank them for everything
that they've done for us.

Beautiful. Everything that they
did to support you through this process, and
know that we are all in debt

and grateful for them
for sticking with us and seeing it through. I love it.

Hugs all around. Beautiful. We're going to give you
guys a moment for that. That is fantastic.

And again, now's
the time to cry. Now's the time to
bring on the tears. And so for our final segment,
we have a little prepared video

that we wanted to show you. Again, it's going to
last for a few minutes. If you feel you want to
honor yourselves throughout,

it's great to hear some
voices, so feel free to do so. And then we will come together
and conclude after that.

So Dylan, if you're
ready, take it away.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Thank you. Thank you again to the friends
and family and all the support

mechanisms. Thank you for joining
us here today, whether in the classrooms
visiting throughout their time.

Attending class. Some of you attended
class in person and joined our graduates
during the journey.

Thank you for listening
when they needed it. Thank you for providing advice. And thank you for just
everything that you do.
And graduates, go get them. Go out there. Stay in touch. Thank you for honoring me.
I have my Juicy J t-shirt on! Go, Juicy J!

Congratulations. And with that, I call
this ceremony to an end.

I will linger for a couple
more minutes for those of you who want to unmute
and say goodbye. Enjoy each other's company
if you're in the room.

Enjoy your loved ones
if you're at home. And I look forward
to meeting you wherever our journeys take us.

Thank you again for
your time and attention, and congratulations from
the bottom of my heart.
[CHEERING AND APPLAUSE]
